review:
Well just receive my transformer, the build... well not going to compare to Prime... but well pretty solid, solid plastic. I counter some little issue when i open and start to set up, little lag, but after the latest update, yeah, still have update... it goes pretty well. Can't tell how stable it is, but for now, it is a pretty solid 5. i will update the review later on. BTW, no wifi issue, even better then my laptop, when it is downloading is fast.

So now i have run several intensive program and games over it, no problem... no overheating... cough*unlike *cough* ipad 3*cough... anyway...ok, the screen resolution may not be as good as prime but, it is more responsive than prime... thumb up.
Run through Antutu Benchmark... just a little under the prime... just tiny little bit.

The issue, i won't say it is a issue, but some one will say it is a issue later, is when i start to charge it, the right corner get warm, a little bit to warm. However, i don't think anyone should freak out, because, it is law of physics. It is plastic, a bad heat conductor. Metal on the other hand can distribute the heat through the backpanel, thus the heat is easier to escape and we won't feel the heat, because the temperature won't be rise up concentrated on one point. So in my opinion it is not a big deal, not at all, don't worry about overheating, because it is not, it is just the nature of plastic.

Ok, go back to pro... because it is 1GB DDR3, when you zoom in the picture store in the pad, it is quicker than prime. so i think it is still a 5 star.

Oh, btw, i just wanna add something, so far so great, i love it even more and the issue is still no screen protector coming out!!!, I know prime's protector would be almost the same just not sure. Well...
Oh, one more, the description on the Pad 300 about the CPU, well technically, it 1.5GHz, since they say Prime's CPU is 1.6GHz. Well just saying

ok... now it is downgrade to 3 stars. The reason, the screen is not good... after over 2 and half hours continues usage... and screen start flickering... these means it cannot handle a long time job. On the other hand, first time i hold this tablet doesn't feel it is cheap, but the longer i get, the cheaper i could sense. This is not a tablet can last about 3-4 years, even the processor would be. So if you wanna change a tablet quickly, like in 1 or 2 years, this is a great choice, but for me, i need a more durable and a more durable tablet that can last over 3-4 years for my use on the go. So sorry ASUS, 3 star. I am returning it.(BTW, i don't really care about the whatever, color vibrate... or any fancy expectation, i just want it to be dependable, and can handle some little heavy jobs. The hardware is really annoying after a week of use. It is so cheap.)

I got this tablet a year ago at Christmas, and I loved it all this time, until a week ago, almost to the day it was delivered, the touch screen gave out.  The digitizer card has failed, and now the tablet is afflicted with "ghost touches".  Apps showing the point of touch on the screen will light up along one edge, showing up to 10 simultaneous touches all along that edge of the screen.  It is random, and cannot be repaired by wiping or hard booting.

On reading up about this tablet, I learned this problem is endemic.  It's not IF your digitizer card will fail, but WHEN it will fail.  Google "tf300t ghost touch" before you make a decision to buy this.  The problem is repairable, but will cost almost the price of the tablet, and you will likely be sending it back again within a year.

A pity, I really loved this tablet, but cannot justify plunking down $300 USD on known bad hardware.

First off: I am, in general, an Asus fan. I own many Asus products, including my beloved 1215B netbook. Unfortunately, the Transformer TF300T is a lemon.

The concept is great: tablet with detachable keyboard/battery with USB port can serve as an ultralite laptop in a pinch.

The aesthetics are great: it looks like a well-made, svelte, elegant design.

But under the hood there is a problem. A big problem. Sure, there are a couple annoyances due to cost savings choices, to keep the price down. No flash on the camera, not ultra high resolution display, no Gorilla glass. All are forgivable. What is unforgivable, however, is the choice of low-end internal memory that reduces the tablet to a standstill -- for minutes -- if 2 operations take place at once. This is most obvious while doing anything over WiFi. Updating applications from Google Play? Just let it run overnight and it MIGHT finish. I started writing this review using my TF300T, but gave up and switched to my cell phone.

I have gone to extremes to solve the issues: rooted, installed alternate ROM, shifted cache and data folders to high speed MicroSD card, run Trim application periodically. It has made an improvement, but it is still pretty bad, and these are not things the average user is willing to do. Apparently the memory problem is present on other tablets in the Transformer line. I won't be buying another until it is clear that the problem has been solved.

Asus should never have let this one see the light of day.

Update (June 2015):
After looking at this thing sitting, unused, on a shelf for the past few months, I decided to give it one more try. I loaded a different ROM: KatKiss (KK 4.4.4) which uses an AOSP ROM with some memory optimizations and F2FS file system support. I'm happy to report that the performance is greatly improved. Highly recommended alteration if you are still suffering a sluggish tf300. Still, it is hard to justify increasing the rating since it was dedicated hobbyists, rather than the manufacturer, who made the necessary fixes.

It you're looking for something small to take notes during class or to watch streaming movies/shows, this is a pretty good machine. If you're looking to get some work done, I'd recommend spending a little more money.

The bad: Asus customer service is terrible. I bought it and it wouldn't charge. I suspected that it was just a bad charging cord, so I called OfficeMax. They told me to call Asus customer service. After a morning of "troubleshooting" over the phone, they said I had to pay to mail the whole package in (tablet, dock, and charging cable). It literally took them a MONTH (I swear I'm not exaggerating) to return the machine, and it WAS the charging cable. I was trying to switch back from Apple, and that was not a good first experience. Looking back, I obviously should have just returned it to OfficeMax.

The good: This machine is hyper-mobile. Compared to my old 15" MacBook Pro, this thing was unbelievably tiny. I primarily used it with Evernote to take notes during summer grad classes, and I've brought it along to work meetings to take/share notes with Evernote. It has a nice touch screen, and the smaller keyboard wasn't too much of a bother (although I wouldn't type a whole report/paper on it though).

Bottom line: It's not the fastest for browsing, switching apps, or general usage. It does, however, work well with Evernote and Netflix. The battery life is great, and it is really mobile. If you just want something smaller to take class notes or watch Netflix when you're going to bed, this might be a good value for you. If you're looking to replace a laptop, you should invest a little more money in a faster tablet/notebook.

Some apps did glitch. The browser app did take a moment to start up and run. I also have had it freeze up and restart sometimes.

Plastic back make it lightweight but felt a little cheap.
Dimensions for the screen made it feel a bit narrow when not in landscape mode.

I have had such an adverse experience that I feel compelled to share it. The short version  within 6 months the adapter blew, at the 12 month mark the screen went. The long version - I am hard-pressed to think of an instance in which I have been more disappointed by a product, and its company. I have had nothing but difficulties with it, and am beginning to truly regret the whole experience.
I was the most vocal of proponents for the T300 for the first 6 months. I LOVED this device. It was easy to use, excellent battery life, responsiveafter 6 months, the adapter gave out. I was treated quite rudely by the staff member at the ASUS service centre (at McGregor, Brisbane) and charged something like $50 for the privilege of replacing it. I was left with the understanding that no warranty covered me in this circumstance as I had purchased the unit whilst living in Japan.
I purchased in April, 2013. In the first week of May, 2014  so, barely a year after purchasing  the screen refused to work. The backlight was working, but no image appeared. I researched online and found this was a common problem with the T300. I contacted the ASUS service line to book my tablet in for a checkup. Upon telling the staff member that I had purchased it in Japan, I was told, not to worry, the warranty and service are international  which would have been nice to know with the adapter! I booked my tablet in.
To be fair, I made a mistake here in not pushing the woman on the phone more  she told me that there would be a $55 assessment fee that would be returned with the repairs quotation. I thought this was odd and asked her for clarification, and she told me essentially the same thing, that the $55 would be returned during the repair process. I confess, I didn't truly understand, and instead of inquiring further, I left it, deciding just to ask the staff at the service centre personally. I heartily recommend that anyone contacting the service centre push for full clarification and details.

I left my tablet in the charge of a significantly more professional employee than my first experience at the McGregor service centre. When I asked him for more clarification on the $55 fee, given that I had been told my tablet was covered by an international warranty, he explained that it would be deducted from the cost of the repairs should I choose to go ahead, which made significantly more sense; but, also took a copy of my receipt and very kindly waved the assessment fee without my asking because I should NOT have been given the impression that my tablet was covered (it wasn't  my initial presumption was correct).
Within a week I was contacted by ASUS to be told the screen installed had been faulty, and the repair cost would be $400+ - $260 for a new screen installation, the rest in labour. I was horrified. First of all, I was sold a faulty product. Second, I had used the tablet barely a year. Third, why on earth would anyone pay the cost of a new item on repairs? Particularly as I now have little reason to believe that an ASUS product has any significant lifespan on it  what guarantee that the screen wouldnt just die again in another year?

Incredibly frustrated at this point by my overall experience with ASUS, I informed the staff member that I was not willing to pay that much for repairs, and let him know how disappointed I was with the short life-span of this product. He admitted as well that I might as well get a new one, and said hed speak to his supervisor to see what could be done.
Two days later I was contacted again to be told that the $55 cost of labour would be wiped, and it would be just the $340-ish for the screen. These figures are completely different to those I was originally quoted. Additionally, both staff members who contacted me told me that the backlight was broken and as it was a part of the screen component, it all needed to be replaced. There never was a problem with the backlight  that was the one thing that was working! I asked for clarification on this and was told that it wasn't brightening enough to show the image. I confess, Im not overly technologically inclined, but this sounded like downright rubbish.
I elected not to get the repairs, and picked up my tablet. When I got home, I discovered the frame on the bottom of the tablet, near the docking ports for the keyboard, had been cracked by ASUS during the assessment process. I was absolutely livid that I had not found this back in the service centre, as words would have been had! I understand that my tablet is broken, but what if I had paid for the repairs? I left it in their care, and they returned it to me in a condition poorer to that I submitted it in.

 I will be looking for alternative means to repair my tablet, or selling it for parts. I am so, so frustrated by this whole engagement, and I would seriously to buy ASUS again on the strength of this, or recommend anyone to buy ASUS.

I've only had my Asus Transformer Pad for about a week but I love it! It is just the right size for watching videos/movies, and playing games, and reading books or articles is a breeze. You can use the screen alone as a touch-screen tablet or dock in on the keyboard and use it as a small laptop.
  While the keyboard is surprisingly heavy, it is still light enough to travel with. I DO have to adjust myself to typing on the keyboard, as my reach tends to extend the placement of the keys, but it is nothing too hard to live with. The built in mouse pad is a nice touch, as attaching a mouse or lugging a wireless mouse around would be bothersome and just one more thing to keep up with.
  The tablet fits nicely in the case I found at Wal-Mart for $10, but of course there is no room for the keyboard. Ideally I will be able to find a case that allows the tablet to dock on the keyboard while in the case, for easy transportation.
  The screen clarity and image density are more than adequate for my needs, but someone like my overly alert boyfriend would want something with better HD qualities. However, I am very happy with the image quality.
  I have had fun playing with my tablet and adding apps...so far I have only surfed the net a few times, but I have added about 6-10 apps, played games, read books through my Amazon Kindle app, and routinely visited sites like Facebook and Pinterest. Everything has worked like a dream.
  The cost (including tax and shipping) through the vendor was less than the pre-tax cost at Wal-Mart...I was happy to feel I received a bit of a bargain!
  I will caution anyone purchasing this tablet that you will have to exercise patience when it first arrives. Mine would not turn on until I had charged it for 8 hours...after which it turned on no problems. I have taken care since then to do as directed in the User's Manual, and run the battery down all the way and fully recharge it again. It is supposed to take less time in the future to bring the tablet to a full charge. Let's hope it works!
  Aside from the weight of the keyboard and the fact that I can't use my case with the keyboard, I don't have any complaints concerning this tablet. It is living up to all my expectations and I am very pleased with its appearance and performance!

First off, this is an outdated device by today's standards. It's even rather overpriced at current market value. It's a decent tablet if you can get it on sale, but otherwise, there are better options today.

With that said, however, I'll be judging the functionality of this tablet based on the time it was released. When this tablet came out, it was one of the more powerful ones on the market. The Tegra 3 was a top-of-the-line SoC and even the lower binned chips in the TF300t were still rather snappy compared to the higher binned chips in the TF700 or TF200. Using the stock Asus Android build, it was a little choppy here and there. While Android itself was largely unmodified in the stock build, Asus added a lot of bloatware to push their ecosystem of services. These apps generally ran in the background and could not be killed/uninstalled. As a result, they ate up a non-trivial amount of processing power and memory. Unlocking and rooting the tablet (A relatively easy process thanks to the good people over at XDA) and installing a custom ROM meant you could overclock the CPU/GPU, and get rid of the bloatware. With that modification, the tablet rivaled anything else on the market, and definitely was one of the better priced options in the high-end market.

The wifi and GPS on the TF300t was greatly improved over the previous TF200, thanks to the plastic body. It still retained that swirled finish, which looked very nice and was practical too, since it provided a better grip.

The single external speaker was pitiful as most tablet speakers are. However, the TF300t speaker was particularly irritating because it was on the side of the tablet when held in landscape. This means that watching a movie or playing a game in landscape (as they should be watched/played) meant that you only got sound out of one side, which doesn't sound like a big problem but it actually is really annoying really quickly considering that tablet speakers tend to be tinny sounding and aurally grating. Imagine someone talking loudly into one ear, and you'll know what it was like to listen to this speaker at any useable volume. If the speaker were centered on the top, this would have been a much better location for it.

The resolution is 1280x800, with the Android notification and home bars on the top and bottom, meaning effective screen resolution was basically 720p. For a 10" tablet, this is adequate, but pixels are noticeable when you're doing up-close reading or surfing. There was also some light bleed on the edges of the screen, noticeable only when viewing dark images/video. This was a common problem for this model, and in general, is a common problem with IPS screens.

The biggest drawback to this tablet is the 1GB of RAM. Devices began coming out shortly after this tablet that had 1.5GB and 2GB of RAM, and the extra memory makes a huge difference in Android, probably more so than a faster processor would.

All in all, it was a good tablet at the time it came out, and is still a decent tablet. There were no glaring deficiencies, as the TF200 had. The dock was a nice option. As long as you know what you're getting (which is old technology), and you are smart about the price you should pay for that technology, you will be happy with this tablet.

Was a fan of the "Transformer" design from the moment I saw it - so it saddened me to give it a low rating - but I'll explain.

First, the plus of the design.  It uses the Android operating system, allows for an optional (highly recommended) keyboard dock, and has a fairly nice system bump by ASUS to give it a slight advantage over the stock Android design.  ASUS has supported this up to the Jelly Bean upgrade (no official Kit Kat as of this review - but there are unofficial upgrades for it), which is a nice upgrade over the pre-installed Ice-Cream.  Scrolling between screens is smooth and software loading is fast and responsive.

Now the bad - and I will caveat, this is only my experience, so I can't say if it is common or not.  Approximately 3-4 months after purchase, my tablet would reboot by itself whenever I touched it.  I called ASUS and they issued an RMA, stating that it was likely a short in the tablet.  After a few weeks away (and complete loss of my data on the tablet), it was returned and worked great.  Then, 2-3 months later, the connector ports that hold the tablet to the optional keyboard started showing signs of stress.  The plastic of the frame at these locations is thin and poorly made.  I use this tablet at home and only to surf while I am sitting watching TV.  How the wear was so great as to cause cracking of plastic is beyond me.  Even the center port, where the tablet actually interacts with the keyboard cracked.  The plastic is a bit thicker, but still too thin to be a secure point between two pieces of equipment that, while light, put stress on each other.  This eventually led to a small crack along the back of the tablet between the two ports.  I sent it in to ASUS for review and they stated - "Nothing found - no repairs necessary."  Then just this month (right after my warranty expires of course) the tablet started experiencing the same issue it did the first time - auto rebooting whenever I touch the tablet cover.  Sent it back in and looking forward to seeing how much ASUS wants to charge me to fix something that shouldn't be an issue to begin with.

Overall, I've lost my data twice (as the reboots eventually lead to data loss) and had to send it in three times for repair.  I'm hoping this repair is my last, but I am now very hesitant to recommend an ASUS tablet to anyone.  It very well could be a lemon and not indicative of ASUS quality control, but it has left a bad taste in my mouth.  I love ASUS motherboards, but can honestly say it does not extend to their tablet products right now.  I gave it a 3 of 5, however, as I have found it to be very useful and responsive during those periods that it worked without issue.  I believe such technology should last longer than 1 yr, which is how long the warranty is good for - but I'll hold off on a final verdict until they fix it this time.  I'd recommend looking at other products unless enough of the feedback from owners is positive without issue.

My one year with the TF300T has been a very disappointing one. I bought the tablet based on several reviews that claimed it was about the best android tablet on the market then--given its speed, innovation, affordability, and upgradeable android OS. However, the TF300T has mostly been erratic and clunky for me. Compared to the iPad I recently bought for my wife, it is really nothing much to write home about. I think Asus focused more on innovation than giving this machine a soul that really gets it going.

As non-Nexus tablets go, Asus tends to have great specs. Unfortunately, Asus also likes to clog them up with a custom skin that slows everything down to a crawl. The TF300 has a great developer community. I ROMed this tablet with a Kitkat (android 4.4) ROM and it runs very very well now. If you are not going to ROM it you might be disappointed with the speed of the device using the stock ROM it comes with. Especially if you are going to use their feature to have multiple accounts.

The display is good but does not do gradients well. Good visibility and good view angles. But in gradients you will see some banding. The resolution is good but not great (not in the post Retina-display era of Android anyway). Color reproduction is excellent though.

Battery life has generally been very good for me though it will not hold up great under gaming. It does seem to charge fast though and hold a charge very well while the display is off. The included SD slot makes it very expandable and is something that Nexus devices will never have. With the optional keyboard dock, expansion and battery life are increased dramatically even further. The keyboard is very well implemented (snaps on and off securely). Though it makes the tablet a lot heavier and bulkier.

So if you are looking for a mid-range tablet and do not want to wait for the new Nexus 10, this is a good alternative. Not the best, but fast enough to be relevant in 2014 and with a decent display and great expandability.

I upgraded to the TF300 after my Iconia 500 tablet died. I didn't get the keyboard attachment for this tablet so I can not speak to that. I've actually had this for about 9 months now, so I've been using it pretty extensively.

The biggest complaint I have about this tablet: It's sluggish. After waking it up it may take 5-10 seconds before it starts responding to touching the screen. Or it may respond almost immediately. If I launch an app, I often have to wait up to 5 seconds before I can even interact with anything in the app. I have to reboot the tablet periodically to regain performance.
This sluggishness doesn't make it unusable. Once an app is running and in-focus, it runs fine. It just seems that background processing and context-switching is very poor in this tablet. I do not know how much of that is the specific flavor of Android and how much of it is hardware.

A second problem I have which may be linked to the sluggishness is the touch-screen doesn't seem to respond properly sometimes. Even when an app is clearly running (screen is updating, sound is playing, etc) I sometimes have to tap a button or icon a dozen times before the tablet realizes I'm actually interacting with it. I've verified this isn't due to calibration settings or the screen being dirty.

By contrast the Acer Iconia 500 was very responsive both to touch input and general app performance. It has a lower-power CPU and less storage capacity, yet this supposedly more powerful tablet ultimately feels like a downgrade. :(

My advice is you are considering this tablet is to try and use one for a while, such as borrowing a friends or trying it in a store. Or pick-up a used one and sell it if it doesn't meet your needs. For me, I regret buying it but since it was a sudden replacement need and not a planned upgrade, I consider it an acceptable in-betweener while I wait for the opportunity to buy a better tablet.

I've had this tablet for just over a year now, and once again, ASUS has impressed me. I used to use an ASUS netbook for school, and it was replaced by this tablet/dock combo.

Performance: The tablet performs exceptionally well, and it hasn't really had a problem running any program I throw its way. Great for playing games, and all of the regular social networking stuff (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Flipboard, etc). I also used it for school work, and never had a problem. I used open-office or Polaris to open PDFs, powerpoint slideshows, and word documents with no problems. I typed up reports and was even able to edit notes in powerpoints during classes and I never really missed anything. I've even used this thing for a few presentations and it has never let me down (Micro-HDMI port and those cables can be cheap if you know where to look!).

The real benefit though, is the battery life. With the dock, this thing can be used for about 14-16 hours continuously without having to charge. This is, to me anyways, unheard of! I have NEVER had to take the charger out of my home when taking this thing around with me. Even if you forget to charge it the day before (or even 2 days), you can squeeze out a 3rd day of heavy usage at times and you wouldn't have a problem.

Wifi is pretty good, and can sometimes pick up a signal as good or better than my phone (I've used iPhone 4s, GS3, GS4, HTC One S, Z10, etc). Speakers also work really well, and can be fairly loud. When I go on trips, my friends use this to play music and we're never left wanting more.

Good but not great: The screen. Great resolution, clear and bright colours. BUT, when you take it outside (or it is in direct sunlight) it can be difficult to read. For indoor use, this isn't really an issue, but for the rare and odd time I'm outside and happen to want to use the tablet, it isn't quite as bright as I'd like it. Still usable, but maybe could be better. I'm sure for the higher model (Transformer Prime), this isn't an issue, so this isn't really a complain as much as a wishlist item / suggestion.

After a year of constantly clicking in and out of the keyboard, I haven't noticed any signs of wear. Still clicks in cleanly, and removes just as fast. The switch mechanism is flawless, and I can't think of a better system. Even holding from the screen and dangling the keyboard, there is really no give; great job on the design there!

Keyboard is pretty good for the size, and I've never had a problem with it. This may be because I've used 2 netbooks prior to owning this tablet, so your mileage may vary in this regard. I would recommend trying it first if you've never used a keyboard on a 10inch laptop, because I'm sure some people out there may not like it or find it usable. You can also disable the trackpad, which I do on a regular basis, because sometimes just reaching out and touching the screen is faster. That being said, the trackpad does support gestures for scrolling and what-not, so if you feel like keeping your screen finger-print free, that's a suitable alternative for you.

One thing that deserves special mention, however, is ASUS constant support for this tablet. In the year that I've had it, this thing has received updates REGULARLY! Something that is unheard of in most of the Android community, but something that I would commend ASUS for. Whenever a new version of Android comes out for the new nexus device (Nexus 4, 7, whatever) it seems like only days later the update will come to this tablet. Absolutely phenomenal support from these guys, and I would not hesitate to buy more devices from them in the future. In fact, I will probably almost exclusively buy devices from them now, seeing as my 3 year old netbook is still being used everyday by my little sister and has yet to have an issue with! There are already about 900 reviews for this product on Amazon, but ASUS earned my support here so I have no trouble in recommending them to friends and family.

10-02-2013 - An update I hope will help others. I still have this tablet. After much much much reading, I decided to see if I can fix this first. The OS is 4.1.1 and I don't recall what the firmware was. The display would go blank and not wake up, sometimes hours later and after several presses of a button. I noticed that every time I plug the adapter into the docking slot and into a charger or USB port, the display would pop back on. Sometimes it gave me time to play with it. So, I started by disabling the screensaver, then screen lock and then passwords. I manually checked for updates... it did over 30 updates to firmware, OS and stock app software. Yikes! This took a long time and it rebooted several times as a result. I now have the latest firmware and running Android 4.2.1 with latest stock apps. Also, utility software was updated several times too. The unit was staying on for long periods of time. In fact, as long as I occasionally did something on it, say every less than 10 minutes, the display would never go blank. However, it still went blank and could not be awakened. Do more reading, now with a narrower problem, I found a possible solution... turn off the sync app! Even when connected to a PC, turn it off!!! My tablet has been on now for 6 hours, no screensaver remember, and I can live with that! I am going to keep an eye on it and see if it still will have this problem. I do have a simple solution for myself, I can make a small battery powered circuit to plug into my USB to Dock connector adapter to re-awaken it as needed. This is almost a 1 year later review. I've got one of this for my wife and a Nexus 7 (v. 1) for myself. We both use Nexus 4 smartphones, so this house it's pretty much full of Android devices. Many of my comments will compare this tablet against my Nexus 7 since they are both very similar tablets: except for the screen (similar resolution but the Nexus 7 has more ppi density than the ASUS TF300), the both have the same RAM and similar CPU/GPU speed and performance.

OVERALL DESIGN

Although I prefer the Nexus 7 smaller form factor, the ASUS Transformer it's definitely better for watching videos. The speakers on the ASUS TF300 are WAY MUCH BETTER than the Nexus 7 and the screen size is really great for this kind of tasks.

Screen is very responsive but I feel that the plastic/glass surface is placed too far away from the LCD screen, so the touchness is "different" from other tablets or smartphones that I regularly use. Of course, this is a very personal feeling and it doesn't interfere at all with the responsiveness of the screen.

The body of the tablet is very comfortable (rounded corners and smooth lines) and has a very decent design. Materials are good and resistant and is very well assembled (the Nexus 7 is not assembled as well as this). The tablet itself is not too heavy.

The surface on the back has a concentric circles pattern which is really cool for improving the grappling, but is not nearly as good as the back of the Nexus 7 that has a different kind of material which emulates the feeling effect of a driving glove. My wife hates the back of the ASUS TF300 (we all have our obsessive-compulsive disorders) because of the noise that their fingernails make against it, but nevertheless, if you are like us and buy your device along with a case (strongly suggested: for this tablet, we got the Poetic StrapBack Protective Case for Asus Transformer TF300 along with a MoKo Invisible Screen Protector Films for ASUS Transformer Pad TF300) you won't notice any of this since the case covers the back of the device.

Buttons are well placed and very easy to press.

Charger is small and cable is long enough (another improvement over the damn short cable of the Nexus 7) to use the tablet directly hooked to the wall socket.

SPEED AND PERFORMANCE

For a tablet originally released on May 2012 (I'm writing this review on September 2013) its overall speed is very good but not the best on the market. I'm talking about 1 or 2 seconds (sometimes) while loading apps or half a second while switching apps. Maybe it's a software issue, because this ASUS TF300 is currently running Android 4.2.1 (still, one of the latest) while my Nexus 7 it's a little faster (just a little) and runs on the last 4.3.

Just to make sure: this IS NOT A SLOW or crappy generic tablet. It's a very good one but is not the fastest you could get. Comparing the ASUS TF300 with My Nexus 7, I feel the same as comparing my Nexus 7 to my Nexus 4 (the Nexus 4 is faster than both tablets).

Videos and typing tasks run smooth. No lags and it doesn't hang. We don't play too much games on our tablets, but they run smooth as well (even heavy 3D games).

HDMI, CAMERAS AND MICRO-SD

For me, the three main features of the ASUS T300 over the Nexus 7 are the Micro HDMI port, a rear 8MP camera and the Micro SD slot. I can't talk about the Micro HDMI port and Micro SD slot because we haven't used them, but it's really great to know that you can get more of your tablet, like connecting it to a Video Beam for a lecture or presentation (or just to watch a movie on a bigger screen).

We got the 32GB model, that is more than enough for most of the tasks that you'll want to do on a tablet (that's the reason we haven't tested the Micro SD yet). Compared to the Nexus 7 8GB, this is a major diference: I'm constantly out of disk space with my 8GB tablet and have to clean old files / unused apps constantly.

The rear camera is the second major improvement over the Nexus 7 (v. 1) that doesn't have a rear camera at all. Of course, this kind of devices are not made to use them as photo cameras, but you can certainly take pretty decent photos and record HD videos. The front camera in both devices are pretty much the same low quality and work mostly for videochats.

BATTERY LIFE

My wife is not a heavy user as me with her tablet, but the ASUS TF300 definitely has a great battery life. She never runs out of battery while on the street, neither do I with my Nexus 7.

ADDITIONS

If you type A LOT in your table and use it for work, you could get the ASUS Transformer Pad Mobile Dock TF300T which is phisycal keybord that can be attached to the tablet, converting it on a full Netbook (and extending the battery life as well). We didn't bought it (it's on our Wishlist), but the reviews are pretty good.

OVERALL CONS

The first thing I really don't like about this tablet is its lack of a standard Mini USB port, both for charging and connectivity. All of our other gadgets use the same USB port, so it's very easy to exchange cables or even chargers, and if you are somewhere else and need to send a heavy file to a desktop PC, it's always more comfortable and fast to do it over a MiniUSB-to-USB cable that most people have on their desks, rather than WiFi. Of course, you can always carry your own cable and charger with you.

The second thing that this tablet could have, it's a magentic sensor to turn off the screen while using protective cases. My Nexus 7 has this function and it's really great to be able to close the case cover that automatically turns off the screen. With the ASUS TF300 you have to manually switch the screen off (or wait until it goes off automatically after a few seconds).

CONCLUSION

Right now, this tablet it's still a pretty good deal if you wan't the save some money. Compared to the Nexus 10 -which is somewhat  on the same price/specs range- the ASUS TF300 it's about 20% cheaper, and compared to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 it's still cheaper (and with better specs). I think ASUS made this tablet to last for at least a good 3 years.

This tablet is really goodfor reading, browsing the web (always over WiFi, because IT DOESN'T HAVE A SIMCARD SLOT FOR 3G ACCESS), typing and watching videos. You won't be disapointed.

If you are more towards the Nexus 7 idea, then you could save even more money. But, in this case, after 1 year of use and the lack of rear camera and limited disk space / no micro SD slot, I strongly suggest you to get the new Nexus 7 v. 2 (FHD), which solves the camera and disk space problems of the Nexus 7 v. 1. Just notice that if you are accustomed to 10-inch tablets, you may feel the Nexus 7 too small. Personally, I like it over any 10-inch tablet, precisely for it's easy to handle size and lightweight.

Most important: anything yo do, just don't get one of those cheap generic tablets. I have had all the bad possible experiences with cheap models including performance, responsiveness, battery life and crappy materials.

I bought this tablet and keyboard combo with the idea of having the best of both worlds: the ability to work like I can on my laptop, with the ability to separate the two parts and read like I do with my Kindle.

The Good:

 - The keyboard and tablet easily snap together and separate with a push of the lock switch. The tablet pauses for a moment while it disconnects or reconnects, but recovers in about a second. The tablet works very well on it's own, but the keyboard offers some great bonuses:

---------- 1) It's nice to have a keyboard and track pad for those normal computing tasks. It makes typing and web browsing a lot more fluid and it saves unnecessary fingerprints on the screen.
---------- 2) The keyboard has its own battery and will keep the tablet battery charged. That allows you to not only extend your battery life overall, but lets you charge the tablet when you've been using it alone, even when no AC power is available.
---------- 3) It provides a built in stand for watching movies and other media without the need for a cover that acts as a stand. It also provides navigation controls without touching the screen.
---------- 4) The keyboard helps protect the tablet when you don't have a sleeve or case.
---------- 5) Extra ports and storage: You get a USB port (which will operate portable hard drives, thumb drives and AC powered external hard drives), a full size SD card slot and an easier way to plug in an AC adapter than the bottom port on the tablet.

- The tablet itself is thin and light - thinner and lighter than an Ipad. Some friends of mine with Ipads were actually surprised at how light it was for the size.

- Unlike some tablets, the screen is seamless across the surrounding bezel. This keeps dirt from collecting at the screen edges and makes a more finished appearance. The screen is bright and detailed and seems very responsive, other than times when the system is updating or doing some other task that can slow things down a bit. That's not an issue with the screen so much as stuff going on that takes up system resources now and then.

- You get both front and rear facing cameras: 1080p, 8MP rear and 720p, 1.2 MP front. Despite the tiny lenses, the video and photos I shot with the rear camera were quite good and the rear was more than acceptable for video conferencing.

- The tablet itself has a microSD card slot. Using NTFS, I was able to use a 64GB card. If using FAT, 32GB will be your max size. The built in memory is 32GB.

- The tablet has a micro HDMI port and it connected easily to my TV. Again, that's a micro HDMI, not mini like what comes on laptops. My old tablet had a mini port, so I had to buy a new cable to use this tablet with my TV.

- The docking port on the bottom is multi-use: It can be used to charge the tablet with the included AC adapter, it can be used to connect it to the docking keyboard and it can be used to connect external adapters, such as a USB or a full sized SD card reader if you don't have the keyboard with you (both available separately).

- The unit also has a headphone jack for audio playback only - no mic (there is a built in mic, but it's merely acceptable quality), hard volume controls on one edge (out of the way so you won't hit them when you don't want to, but still in easy reach) and a speaker on the back side.

- The battery life lasts pretty much all day long. I was able to watch videos for several hours and still have plenty of battery left over, especially with the keyboard attached. This would mean no issues with battery life when flying and the in flight movie isn't your thing.

- The system can access both Amazon and Google's App stores. It can likely go to others, but I haven't tried. Through them, I was able to download the Netflix app, Kindle Reader, Firefox for Android, Photoshop Touch, B&N Nook and a whole lot of games. Through Amazon, I can easily access my digital music, though I-Tunes is out (at least directly, anyway - some apps will let you sync it, but I've had less than 100% success in that regard). Though I don't use them, you can also get apps for Twitter, Facebook, Dropbox, Pandora, and pretty much everything else. Even among apps that are Apple only, there seems to be no shortage of apps that work similarly enough to do the job on a much lower price tag.

- The tablet offers both WiFi and Bluetooth for wireless communication. It's quick to get to the settings to turn them on and off and to activate airplane mode.

- The tablet does offer GPS functions, but it's really too big to use as one. Your phone is still a better bet.

- Some helpful settings include easy power management (I keep my system set on performance mode since Battery life isn't an issue), the ability to lock screen rotation (lets you read while laying down without the page rotating) and quick access to screen brightness and overall system settings. You can even take screen shots if you need to.

- Like most Android systems, you can use one of three ways to access your apps: the main home desktop screens (there are up to five you can flip between - I have productivity apps on the main one and games on a secondary one), the apps menu (assessable from the button on the upper right of the home screen) and through the recently used apps menu in the lower left that remembers where you recently were until you do a full reboot. Apps from the main apps menu can be copied to the home screens of your choice. There are also plenty of screen widgets to add functionality to the desktop, like clocks and hot links to email and other apps.

- Overall, the quality seems very good, though there is a bit of noticeable flex in the seams between the backing and the screen. Since it's mostly plastic, it's to be expected. It doesn't seem like it will fall apart, though. There's also a bit of edge light leakage, but it's not overly noticeable in normal lighting and the benefit of a wider viewing angle offsets that minor gripe. My older tablet had terrible viewing angles, so this is a nice change of pace.

- The Google Voice search worked well, but it was easier to just open the browser and type for me than it the mic button and speak. It did work well in noisy environments, but it felt silly to talk to it around others. Next thing they'll come up with is some silly glasses you wear around everywhere....

The Bad:

- The worst of the system is the speaker. It's on the back and mono. At least I think it's mono. Since it's all one piece on one side of the back of the case, it's sounds mono. If there were two speakers at each end of the long dimension (even on the back like the current one is) it would be a huge improvement for hearing audio when you don't want to use headphones. It would still likely not sound great, but it really can't get much worse - except for my old tablet that had a single, dime sized speaker on the back you could barely hear. This system is marginally better. At least you can understand speech properly when listening to dialog in video. For music, you'll really want headphones.

- It lacks Flash. There are plenty of people who will claim you don't need it, but you do. I can't tell you how frustrating it is to click on a video, only to get the message "this video not supported by your device". Grrrrr. It would be one thing if the industry were simply moving away from Flash and not using it going forward, but we aren't close to being there yet, so dumping support for it is crazy. The worst part is, the newest versions of Android won't even let you download Flash for Android - and you do get the latest on this system (or soon after you turn it on when it updates everything).

- The front camera isn't 16x9 for video for no reason at all. The rear camera is (though is 3:2 like DSLR cameras for photos), but the front facing camera is a pillar boxed 4x3 frame with no way to change it. I'm not sure why they went 4x3 for the rear when there's more than enough resolution in the sensor for 16x9. Now, if several people want to get in on the chat, they have to really, really like each other and have great hygiene in order to squeeze into the frame. I also do wish you could set whether you want the photos to be 3:2, 4x3 or 16x9. Most people will view the photos they take with this device on the device. It would be nice to be able to shoot in a wider format when something merits it.

- Finally, and I'm fully able to admit this, it's not an Ipad. The fit and finish won't be as good, the screen doesn't have as high a resolution and there will be some apps you won't be able to get - at least not the exact same ones, anyway. You also won't have native I-Tunes support. Finally, unlike an Ipad, there's no 3G/4G option built in. However, you should be able use a USB dongle either with the keyboard or (I assume) with the USB adapter for the tablet, assuming drivers exist. I assume they do, since my last tablet offered the ability to add that very thing.

Summary:

- In short, the ability to add nearly unlimited storage with the ports on the keyboard, the ability to add storage directly to the tablet, the HDMI output and the dual cameras and very nice looking screen make this an excellent system. While updating tasks occasonally slow things down, the system is generally quick and responsive in performance mode.

The result is, I've almost been able to replace my full sized laptop for most tasks except Photo and video editing (there are Android Apps, including Photoshop, but the desktop versions are just so much better and faster to work with for any real work).

Ironically, one of the simplest things still gets me back to the desktop, too: I have yet to come up with an app that truly works as well as Outlook for my desktop system for organizing mail from multiple accounts. Any app I've tried seems to always separate the accounts, which means shared custom folders never seem to work right. That's not a ding on this tablet, it's Android. With Outlook on my laptop, I can set up custom folders that all accounts can have use of based on rules I set up (including a single trash bin). I've found a couple of Android apps that almost get there, but not quite.

Likewise, with such a large screen, I tend to want to visit the full desktop versions of web sites because the mobile ones often suck and the web apps are often worse by limiting functions, options and content. The problem is, some sites don't play as nicely as they should.

In the end, though, Android devices have come a long, long way in both power and performance and this tablet is right up there with all the good ones. Perhaps when it's time for me to upgrade down the road, many of my issues will be address. Right now, it's very close, but just a bit shy of being there. It's good enough for now, though.

However, today I lost faith in Asus products, because I left it on the table (no one touched it), and when I opened it the next day, there was a crack, and my touch screen would not work. It is two days before the warranty is up, but I firmly believe that if I spend 380 dollars (500 including the dock), my product should work for more than one year.

I contacted the warranty people twice, and both times I was told that if there is physical damage, then it voids the warranty, and I would have to pay 180 (or 230 according to the second guy's estimate) to get it fixed. Since it's now a 315 dollar product, I'm not going to pay that much to repair something that was not my fault. I believe that the problem is with the dock. I keep it in the dock most of the time, and when it broke, it was in the dock. The flat tablet does not mesh perfectly with the dock, and there is space between the keyboard and the tablet even when it's supposed to be completely closed. I believe after time, the strain of opening and closing it broke the tablet screen + digitizer.

I understand that there's no way they can know that I didn't smash my tablet on something, but I know that I didn't, and I'm letting everyone who might buy this know that this tablet is not the quality that I would expect for a $300 item, unless they are okay with it breaking within a year.

Although I've always thought that apple products are overpriced, if I'm going to pay 300 dollars per year for a tablet, I may as well spend an extra 200 on an ipad 2 with gorilla glass that will last 2 or 3 years.

This is my first venture into both android and tablet and I'm not a techie so I'm writing this mainly for others who are new to tablets. So far (little over a month) it works great although it freezes periodically which I discovered through research is pretty common. You hold the on and volume buttons simultaneously for 15 seconds to force start, use the volume button to select android and then press "on" button to force start. It supposedly is capable of Flash but it turns out if you download the adobe flash app without doing a long complicated process called rooting it doesn't work and, oh, btw, if you root you could lose everything including your warranty. Finally found Puffin browser which has built in flash and it does everything I need--it's also faster than the other three browsers I have on it.  But I'm not seriously into games so my experience might not work for you if you are.
The biggest shock for me has been the amount of stuff you need to buy after paying for the tablet. This one doesn't have scratch proof screen so needs screen protector. The ASUS keyboard that goes with this is around $100--I wound up researching a bit and discovered that there's an Amazon bluetooth keyboard for kindle and android that works for this at around $25. Just got it so this is the first thing of any length I've typed via tablet as I LOATHE the digital keyboard.  Needs a case.  I got a leather one (Poetic) for $19.99. Also, I get a little tired of constantly enlarging the screen and then having it pop back to small and since my fingers (which are slim) are too big to click precisely when it's small I also ordered styluses.
I got the special plug adapter to be able to use it with computer but none of my cables worked and then I discovered there are lots of apps for sharing files across wi fi so I've never needed to use it.  But if you need to hook up to computer you may also need to purchase a cable.
I agree with other reviewers that the charger that comes with it is obviously cheap.  It works and I've been very careful with it so I think it will be fine for a while but add to the list of purchases that eventually you'll need a better charger.
So I could barely afford the tablet and I already have about $100 more into the extra stuff (George Carlin was so right about stuff needing stuff...).  I noticed that it's true of most of the tablets that there's all kinds of extras you need so bear it in mind when you set a price limit--if you buy a tablet at the top of your price range, then you're going to spend way over if you want or need any or all of the other stuff.
I've also learned to watch out for the free apps -- not only do many of them keep interrupting games, etc. with ads but they access your internet connection and download stuff you don't want.  I imagine that's not unique to this tablet.
I noted that other people have complained it's sometimes slow and the apps are sometimes slow and I've found that to be true though sometimes it seems to be my internet connection.  A few apps I've just given up on and so far I've always found something else that wasn't as sluggish.
It's a little heavy as a reader but I'm looking forward to taking it on a trip this spring with a few dozen books downloaded on it. It's more comfortable if it's resting on something because of the weight but otherwise doubles well as a reader.

The main reason this won over a Kindle Fire for me was the size and I'm really glad I didn't get anything with a screen any smaller than this though I'm sure the Fire is also good.
Update 4/22/13:  finally got a mini-HDMI cable and discovered another issue.  I could get a perfect picture but no sound.  Did some research and found dozens of people in several forums with the same problem.  This model uses Jellybean and the last two updates allegedly have a glitch that wipes out audio in the hdmi connection.  I just wanted to try it out as a preliminary step toward possibly dumping cable and using Roku plus Hulu or Netflix so it's not a big loss for me at the moment since I'd never used streaming.  If you use it a lot though you might want to think twice because I can find no sign that they're planning to fix this issue.  Pretty disappointed I can't try this out.

I did A LOT of research before greeting this tablet, and I think it paid off.
PROS:
Has a micro hdmi input.  With a hdmi A to hdmi B cable I can watch video stored on the tablet or stream video through the tablet ( wireless) to any TV.
Has a microSD slot.  No USB slot, but don't need one.  Have several different ways of getting data on/off the SD card if needed.  I can use Bluetooth if I want to attach another input device.
Screen resolution is what I wanted/ expected.  I'm not a heavy gamer, and don't use the tablet for drawing fine art.  We use it to watch movies, surf the web and "mobile" computing.  We think the resolution is very good.
Battery life is very good, from our experience.  We can play for hours on this thing before it needs a charge.
CONS:
None, but will address what others have brought up.
Have had the charger/tablet get warm after multiple charging sequences (plugging/unplugging/plugging the charger without letting the tablet fully charge).  We don't use the tablet while it's charging.  And when I say warm I'm talking lukewarm, in no way hot.
I did have the power button bug out once, but a reboot ( down volume and power button at the same time, then the up volume after the screen starts) fixed that problem.

This is a windy review...  The TF300 is a excellent tablet for many reasons.

First of all, I'm thankful for purchasers that have submitted reviews to give me a grasp of what to look for in a tablet (both good and bad).  I spent some time reading reviews of tablets that were out there to get an idea of what qualities to look for.  My wife has a Acer Iconia 100a which is solid but already a generation out (at least).  At first I wouldn't even pick it up because the idea of apps was so foreign.  I'm still in my PC world. Within the last 6 months I began seeing the value in being able to load books, articles and documents onto this kind of device.  I also saw the value of a camera that takes decent pictures.  I did enjoy the interface with my car's USB for music and audio books.  Oh and kids...  Childrens games that are interactive are invaluable.  I was won over to the idea so I began exploring.

I'm in my 40's and things are changing.  The 7in screen is getting to be too small, so I started my search in the 10in screen.  I saw the Xoom and was contenting myself with the idea but my nephew told me ASUS was the way to go, so I switched gears and began to look at what was there.  There was Samsung, Toshiba, Motorola, Acer and Asus in the android running.  So many options.  I decided to open my eyes to the Ipad since the last generation is now in price range.  I read a little and decided I was too old fashioned and settled into the PC mindset.  I've got a laptop (w/vista) at home and my phone is pay-per-minute w/a querty keypad.  Android was more familiar and closer to my computer logic.  See you later Ipad.  The Kindle HD had a huge discount and was very tempting, but the lack of gps and camera on back lost that idea quickly. I like gadgets with lots of optional gadgets.

I began researching and words like IPS, 'rooting', nits, and ICS intimidated me.  I didn't let that stop me because if it is important, I will persevere.  I hit online reviews at Cnet and Egadget to help me along the way.  After a point the running came to current technology.  Which chipsets and processors would be around for the longest?  I narrowed my seach to the quad core offerings because each of them had the 'ice cream sandwich' operating system (OS) and were upgradeable to 'jelly bean'.  Upgradeability.  My wife's Iconia was upgraded to 'ice cream sandwich', but is not upgradeable to 'jellybean'.  Product support for a few years to come is an important aspect.  Price was also very important.  I like the convenience, and that is what these devices are, convenience.  At $500, I began seeing replacement laptops for my antique of 2007.  No, no, I won't go there.  So in the running were the Acer A700, the Toshiba Excite 10, the Asus TF300; ...and the ASUS TF700 and the NEXUS 10...  Oh wait a minute where did that $500 thing go.  The new generation of vivid screens and memory and power were starting to blur my vision.  Getting back to the three nice priced Tegra 3 quad cores.  All seem similar on paper, the Toshiba Excite has a flash for the camera and two speaker stereo sound and gorilla glass.  The Acer A700 has the vivid 1920x1200 display, no flash and two stereo speakers.  The Asus TF300 has a 8.0MP camera, only one speaker and no flash, but is $50 less than the competition.

Getting into some details, the Acer was reviewed to get hot, and the Excite and Asus were very similar in their offering, so price won out in that case.  I read that the ASUS is has less preloaded apps to deal with.  I also read that the Asus was faster at processing that the other two on various apps.  Battery life, they are all reviewed around 8hrs.  All of these shaped my understanding of what was there.  In the end price won out for me.

Now for the driving...
I got my tablet, immediately charged it before turning it on.  I then affixed a purchased screen film protector and slid it into a leather case to protect it.  I powered it on and watched and waited.  It took nearly a minute to power up.  My wife's starts up in similar time.  Once it started, I input my wi-fi passwd and when it got signal it almost immediately began downloading new firmware.  No issues with connecting with Wi-fi, almost immediate.  This took nearly 20 minutes and with a restart the 'ice cream sandwich OS' was gone and I had 'jellybean'.  I had read reviews about 'ice cream sandwich OS,' and it having issues of freezing up and the loaded browser freezing up and asking you to wait or cancel.  I also read of the virtual keyboard not being as attentive.  I have to agree with these assessments as my wife's tablet suffers that.  The 'jellybean' does correct a lot of those issues and the browser is quicker and doesn't freeze up the same way and the keyboard is attentive.  I did as others suggested and loaded another browser - Chrome which helps the 'ice cream sandwich' a bunch.

Touchscreen and SD Card
The Asus TF300 has a very good touch interface via their WXGA-IPS... display.  I like how easy it to select, click on and move items.  I can't speak of the Toshiba or Acer A700, but it is worlds better than my wife's tablet.  My age comes out here, but I couldn't get the Micro SD 32 GB card to work.  There was no selection to send pictures there, on downloading, there was no option to select this.  I online chatted with Asus (it does take some patience, so be ready) and they got me to my solution quickly.  There is a 'File Manager' app which lets you look at the tree menu of your tablet and SD card.  You have to find the file location and manually move from your tablet to the SD card (the file tree was similar to that of the pc system).  Initially I thought it was inconvenient, but quickly recognized the value and ability of being able to customize your files.  I like that.  My wife's doesn't let you do this.  In moving files, no matter where you move it, the tablet recognizes the location.  In my exploration I found the loaded Polaris Office to be an excellet app and I found that the Book app renders downloaded .pdf documents clearly. Other apps brought them in faded and grainy.

Viewing and sound
I adjusted the brightness to see just how bright it could be.  In comparison to my wife's it was quite alot brighter.  In reviewing it was supposed to have 400nits of brightness (I'm not sure what that is, but I understand it to be brighter than average).  It is quite bright and in the evenings I usually dim it down for comfort.  In direct sunlight it is hard to see, but is visible.  Clarity, it is clear enough with details showing through on movies on netflix (won't try to compare with HD level of the Acer A700).  I would say it is clearer than my 720p HD 42" flat screen up on the wall.  View angles, it is viewable at almost all angles up to nearly 180 degrees, but it does decline in clarity as you get away from 90 degrees.  My wife's is only viewable from 3 sides, the 4th goes nearly black, yet on one of those sides it stays clear and sharp nearly to 180 degrees.  Interesting.  As far as light bleed on the edges like others have said, it is almost non-existent in darkness, so no bother there.  The sound, it is louder, clearer and fuller than my laptop computer; not in stereo (as claimed), no bass or treble control, no surround sound (my wife's has Dolby with surround option and bass/treble control).  Nothing to brag about, but pleasant when listening to, much like the sound from my cell phone.

GPS, camera, and wifi
I turned on the GPS in my living room and it picked up our location within 30 seconds and was accurate to the room I was in on the map.  It is as quick as my office garmin and fairly sensitive.  The wifi is quick and has decent range and can detect out to about 1200ft away.  The camera is nice and takes good pictures.  Clarity depends on the amount of light.  In incandescent lit rooms it gets grainy.

The app world
I'm learning everyday what is out there on google store and amazon apps.  It is nice to be able to install an app and if I don't like the entire app is removed, as shown by the memory storage decreasing.  Unlike on a pc, where it removes the program, but the software is still in your computer.

Overall it is fast, about as fast as I can click.  It has 3 performance modes that are easily accessable.  I don't do any gaming so the economy mode works well enough for me and saves on battery life. I'm going to enjoy my tablet and have already loaded books, articles, bibles, music, pictures, and maps.  I'm ready to take my show on the road with one thin device rather than a library of books and cds.

After following the instruction in the owners manual I was able to get it to work again (after letting it sit overnight)  On day 11 it stopped working again.  For a tablet with the highest GB storage and the most recent android operating system these products are garbage and I would not recommend that anyone purchase them.

I was in the market for a tablet for six months before I decided on purchasing this tablet. The keyboard dock option appealed to me and after a few months of deliberation, I purchased this tablet.

I own a Galaxy S3 and my sister owns an iPad, which I used to use on a regular basis. I'm not the biggest Apple fan, but I do believe that they have the smoothest tablet out right now. With that being said, the TF300 is still an excellent buy. The functionality of the transformer is mind-blowing. It functions perfectly as a media playback device, gaming device, or "just sitting on the couch surfing the internet" device.

Video Playback
The video quality on this device is amazing. I use the HDMI output to view movies/YouTube videos on my 1080p television and they run flawlessly in HD quality.

Games
This device functions as an excellent gaming device. I've tried several games: the basics (words with friends, angry birds, etc), the graphic intense (THD games: Sonic 4 and Shadowrun), and emulators (N64, SNES). I have yet to run into a hitch. All these games run lag-free. I've also used the USB port to play games with my XBox controller. Coupled with the HDMI output, this makes the device unstoppable.

Browser
Out of the box, the stock browser had a slight lag. Chrome and Dolphin weren't much better. However, once I "modified" it, the browser runs perfect. I would say it's a millisecond slower than my sister's iPad 3 or my Galaxy S3.

Build Quality
Personally, I was pleasantly surprised by the build quality. It did not have the nice metallic build that most tablets have these days, but it still feels good in my hands. I don't think it would survive a fall though.

Features
This is where the TF300 shines. Great specs, HDMI output, micro-SD slot, USB & SD-slot (with the dock). You get a powerful, feature-heavy tablet for a great price.

Battery Life
Amazing. I can get about 15 hours out of this tablet (with the dock). I use this tablet every day, and usually only have to charge twice a week.

Display
Statistically, it doesn't have the best display, nor does it have Gorilla Glass. However, it still an excellent display and I couldn't tell the difference between my sister's iPad's Retina Display until I looked really closely. However, it is a fingerprint magnet.

Concerns
-slightly laggy browser (not really that bad, to be honest)
-screen is a fingerprint magnet (can be fixed with a good screen protector)
-tablet is "top-heavy" when docked (this doesn't bother me at all, to be honest)

Final Comments:
If you want the best tablet available, I wouldn't advise purchasing this tablet. There are better, smoother, faster, better-looking tablets out there (they are also more expensive). However, if you want an excellent tablet, intend on using a tablet for more than just browsing the internet, aren't too concerned with looks, and want a powerful, feature-heavy machine at a great price, then this is the tablet for you. Personally, I would choose this over the iPad any day and I don't feel the Transformer Infinity is worth the extra premium.

This tablet does everything I need it to do and more. I use it for both work and personal use and the battery life is awesome. I'm glad I purchased the tf300 versus the tf100 as the tf300 has much better performance.

The Good:  Amazing screen, fast wifi, and if you install the "keyboard" it includes a docking station, and you can add up to 64gigs of additional storage on top of the 32gigs that are in the unit.  The keyboard also gives you USB connectivity so you can access your flash-drive on the spot too.  That was a really nice add-on.  The audio is also pretty good on this (WAY better than my wife's iPad).

The Bad:  For $450 (I got mine with the keyboard as a package deal) I was expecting a lot more functionality.  DO NOT expect to be able to perform any kind of real work on this thing...  even with a keyboard/track-pad installed.  The hardware/software just won't do it.  I tried to use it to modify some google docs and it was SOOOOOOO painfully slow and tedious, that I just gave up and waited til I got home to update them.  The reality is this is a unit made for (1) playing android games in amazing colors and hi-def (2) watching TV and movies, and (3) playing on facebook and doing some basic web surfing (although this too is painfully slow).  If you like to read, you'll have to download a better e-reader than what comes with it (which is nothing).  I finally settled on the kindle reader, and have been super happy with that.

I guess my point is... if you need a machine that you can work from this will not suffice, and if you're just wanting a color e-reader, there a lot of less expensive options out there that will satisfy your needs.  This unit is targeted at a specific demographic...  spoiled "kids" who play tons of android based video games and play on facebook all day.  It's overpriced for a reader, and under-powered for a work machine... so that really makes it a high priced toy.  Especially when you factor in the fact that it only comes with one charger cable that is really flimsy and only 2 feet long...  You're going to be adding at least $20 to your first order to get a longer cable for the charger.  You'll also be spending a lot of time downloading apps, because this one comes with NOTHING useful pre-installed (not even an anti-virus or e-reader... I mean NOTHING!!!).

****  UPDATE  ****  If you buy this tablet, expect to be ordering another power supply immediately...  the one they ship with the unit overheats and fails.  They run from $15-$45 here on amazon (which is a bargain compared to the in-store pricing).  I have thus reduced my rating to 2/5 based on the continuous nickle & dime BS associated with this unit.  It's a never ending parade of extra purchases just to make it useful.

The unit will appear to be broken (the screen goes crazy and you lose control of anything you're doing with the unit)...  In order to reconcile this, you must perform the following acts...  (1)  Perform a "factory reset" on the unit.  If you have the keyboard and/or use memory cards, it is recommended that they be installed at the time of this action (I don't' know why).  After that has completed, you should then perform a "hard re-boot".  Once this is done you can go back and update all of your apps (they won't disappear, just require re-updating) and then place all of your shortcuts again. My overall opinion of the tablet is that its great, and absolutely worth the price. I'd recommend it to anyone looking into getting a tablet. I wanted a tablet to be a middle ground between my desktop and my Android--portable, but with a large enough screen, and enough processing power, that I can use it like a mobile computer. I use it for reading books, browsing the internet, Skyping, playing games, and when I worked as a private tutor, I used it as a teaching aid. I've had it for about 8 months and loved it the whole time. That said, while it hasn't had any real problems, there are definitely some little things that I would change.

Appearance:
- It's a good looking tablet. I love the blue, I love that it's textured, and I love the glossy screen. The edges are large enough to hold it comfortably without accidentally touching the screen. The display itself is beautiful as well--bright colors and clean edges. I watch videos on it all the time, mostly from YouTube and Netflix, and they always look great.

Operation:
- Mostly very smooth operation. I have no problem with starting programs, connecting to a wifi network, streaming video, playing music, etc. Occasionally, it will lag if I've been playing a game for a while, but only within the game itself; other programs are not affected. Using a task killer solves this most of the time, though a couple times a restart was required.
- The browser is definitely the worst part, but I don't like the default Android browser on my phone either, so this is not a tablet-specific problem. I solved it by installing Chrome, which doesn't close without warning, or constantly bring up messages that the browser is not responding, or make scrolling jumpy. If you're having these problems, switch browsers.

Sound:
- The sound quality is decent. It has one speaker, and that speaker is good, but it's still only one speaker. Don't get me wrong, I have no complaints about this. It's pretty much on-par for a portable device of this sort, and much better than the speaker on my phone, so I'm satisfied.
- The location of the speaker is slightly awkward. It's on the back right-hand side, exactly where I want to put my hand when I'm holding it. None of this is a real problem, though, because I've found that I can still hold it in the same place if I cup my hand around the speaker (which also, incidentally, makes the sound richer/louder/better in general).

Keyboard:
- The pop-up keyboard on the touchscreen is kind of a hassle. Part of the issue is the size. When the tablet is in landscape, the keyboard is pretty large, but still cramped. It's too big for me to hold it in both hands and type with my thumbs, but it's smaller than a netbook keyboard, so typing with both hands like it's a regular keyboard can be tricky as well. Typing is a lot easier when it's in portrait.
- Its version of the Swype system also is pretty buggy. Word recognition isn't great, and it's auto-spacing feature needs work.
- However, one of the fantastic things about this product is that it can plug in to a physical keyboard and be used like a touchscreen netbook. I attach the keyboard if I have a lot of typing to do, and detach it to play games or read e-books. I definitely recommend getting the keyboard, but its still a great tablet without it. I only got my keyboard a few days ago, so I've been using it most of the time without it, and still really enjoyed the product. The keyboard just adds some extra functions.

Charger:
- I'm not sure if I just got a bad wall adapter, or if they're all like this, but mine falls out of the wall with just a light bump. It sort of "hangs" loosely out of the socket, so it doesn't always maintain contact while charging. I've noticed that, if I'm using it while it's charging, the battery logo (the one that shows up in the middle of the screen when the tablet is first plugged in) will show up every 10-15 minutes. The cable itself is perfectly fine, so I just started using a different wall adapter.

In summary: despite a couple small issues, I highly recommend this tablet. If I could go back and select a tablet again, I would stick with this one.

Tablets in theory target a unique market segment somewhere between smartphones & notebooks, and many people have them as a kind of media-toy. If you're interested in buying a tablet for its advantages of size, weight and portability, you now have several alternatives to the default purchase of the IPAD including this ASUS 32gb TF300T.

In an attempt to overcome the annoyance of using an on-screen keyboard, the ASUS has a detachable keyboard dock - a brilliant idea which mostly works well, but the disproportion in weight between the tablet & keyboard means some users might find it less than stable on a table top. If you're using it in a less formal setting (like lying on a sofa) it's OK.

Battery life is very good particularly on the power-saving settings. This is important because the whole idea of a tablet is to use it like a phone, on the move away from a power source, so few people will ever use one connected to the mains. One caution: when first charging out-of-the-box, we couldn't get any life from it at all - not even a charging light, and it took some fiddling around to get it to finally accept charge. Since this initial problem charging has been trouble-free.

The screen doesn't quite have the clear resolution of the IPAD but is very good and more than adequate for a 10.1-inch portable. You can connect multiple-USB devices like a laptop and have the usual big menu of free Android aps to choose from.

pfd is fine but it won't do adobe flash player and won't run MS outlook programs, so you only have webmail. The browser is surprisingly good with a fast connection, video & in-built speaker acceptable though it won't fill a room with music.

Overall I think the ASUS is a good alternative to a laptop if you want a device predominantly for web surfing, media & webmail. The detachable keyboard is a great innovation & removes the objection many people have had to the fiddly & frustrating onscreen keyboard of the IPAD. However:

* It won't replace a Windows or Mac notebook for speed, or run business software like Sage, or Autocad, or even MS Office; but if a browser and media player is predominantly what you want, it's great

* It's not that much cheaper (if at all) than a much more capable budget notebook

* It's not that much lighter or more portable than a lightweight notebook either

* On the other hand it's not as pocketable as a smartphone

Of course, in a couple of years the market will look different again & the tablet as we now know it may be obsolete, replaced with some device infinitely more capable with half the size and weight. For now, the ASUS is a good buy but not a great one, provided you can live with its limitations.

As I am writing this review, my TF300 is running 4.1 jelly beam and not ice cream sandwich. So the quick review for this product is it is a very solid tablet, that for the speed, memory, and screen is well worth the buy. So to go over some of the the real life facts that might change some peoples opinion on if they should get this table or not. First off, this is a fast tablet. Running on normal mode (you have power saver, normal, and performance), this tablets takes on everyday tasks and even some very intensive games like a champ. The screen is also beautiful enough to truly show off to friends and family, and combined with the speed can already get some auto buys from some people. The memory is 32gb, which is more then enough for most people. Some minor downsides include no flash on the back camera (taking pictures can become difficult because of this), a battery life that only lasted between 6-8 hrs, a badly placed speaker that gets muffled if the table is on its back, and no expandable memory. Of course though, all of those downsides are not too terrible and most of them can be worked around. Taking into account that this is a quaid-core tablet that is sub 400$, this tablet has earned my everyday use and I would highly recommend it.
